name: Shikoku Pilgrimage
summary: Hiking to 88 temples on Shikoku Island

all_steps.name: Paris
all_steps.description: Noch einmal schlafen dann gehts los 😍🇫🇷

all_steps.name: First stop - Hong Kong
all_steps.description:
One strike, two cancelled trains and a 12 hour flight later we are *almost* there! 
Now nothing can stop us anymoreee 🇯🇵 🦸‍♀️🤘

location.name: Hong Kong
location.full_detail: Central and Western, Hong Kong S.A.R.

all_steps.name: One sunny day in Osaka
all_steps.description:
Woke up to a surprisingly sunny day in Osaka (makes me want to do Freudensprünge hehe) 🌞
We shared some well deserved pancakes with our fellow hiker friend Tani and continued to spend the day with her. 
We visited the temple Shitennoji and saw a lake full of turtles chilling in the sun just like us 😎 
Que vida! 🐢
Later we enjoyed the sunset from Tsutentaku tower 🌆 We finished the day with Ramen and a walk over the Japanese ‘Timesquare’ called Dotonbori. 
Maike ✨

all_steps.name: Osaka to Tokushima
all_steps.description:
We have arrived on the island of Shikoku! 🏯
Our first stop is a city called Tokushima, we took a 3 hour bus here this afternoon. No hiking yet, only exploring the city and running some last errands before our big day tomorrow 🥾 
On the second picture you can see the traditional pilgrim wear 👕 I might consider buying at least one of the items but I guess you will find out in the next step 😵‍💫🤘 
Maike

all_steps.name: Temple 1-5
all_steps.description:
We woke up at 7am, had a quick breakfast 🥪 at the hostel and headed to Tokushima train station 🚉, where we took a train to Bandō station to finally start our pilgrimage 🥾! 
After leaving the station, a short walk led us to the first temple, Ryōzenji (霊山寺).
We were expecting to see a lot of other pilgrims, but the temples and the path were surprisingly empty. We saw in total maybe 10 other pilgrims. The weather was good: neither too warm nor too cold and no rain. This is also the time of the year where the Sakura (cherry blossom) trees are blooming and we could see a lot of these beautiful flowers along the way 🌸. It seems like we couldn’t have chosen a better time to start our walk!
Today we visited four other temples: Gokurakuji (極楽寺), Dainichiji (大日時), Anrakuji (安楽寺) and Jozōji (地蔵寺).
Tonight we’re staying in a japanese-style accommodation, sleeping in futons instead of beds. After soaking ourselves in a nice and warm ofuro 🧖‍♀️, we’ll have the our first experience eating a japanese-style dinner 🍱 (and breakfast tomorrow).
Bruno 🙇‍♂️

all_steps.name: Temple 6-10
all_steps.description:
After having a japanese style breakfast (with rice 🍚 , misoshiro 🥣 and vegetables) we started our second day with a short walk to temple number 6, Anrakuji (安楽寺) and right after to temple number 7 Jūrakuji (十楽寺), where we met Flynn, a fellow pilgrim from Australia. The first of the two highlights of the day was temple 8, Kumadaniji (熊谷寺), which was surrounded by beautiful trees 🌳 and even-more-beautiful Sakura trees. Temple 9 Hōrinji (法輪寺) followed. Since it was already past noon, we were all starving on our way to the next temple and tried to stop by a bakery that Google Maps pointed us. There was no bakery to be seen but, while asking a random local for directions, we were surprised by our second and most exciting highlight of today: we were invited to his family home 🏡  where we had the chance to meet a lovely couple and their three boys (14, 12 and 9 years old). They offered us a ride 🚙 (which we politely refused) and plenty of fresh water 💦. While we were having a chat with them at their home, they told us that today was the husband’s mom’s birthday: she was turning ninety years old! For our surprise, she showed up 👵🏻 and we could wish her happy birthday 🥳🎈 in person! We left their home with a smile on each one of our faces and headed to our final temple of the day. A steep stairway climb led us to temple 10 Kirihataji (切幡寺). 
We still had 7km to go until our hostel so we decided to stop at a local supermarket to refuel ourselves and rest a little bit. We arrived at our destination for tonight, had a well deserved shower and ofuro (where Maike learned that the mirror wasn’t too low so you could see down there, but rather because you should shower seated 🪑and therefore, see your face in the mirror) 😂
Para fechar nosso dia com chave de ouro 🔑, we decided to eat ramen 🍜 in a Chinese restaurant. Maike guided us there and… we ended up entering the wrong door and going to an Indian restaurant by accident. So, we had no ramen but daal with naan instead. No complaints here 😋! What a day!
Bruno 💫

all_steps.name: Temple 11-12
all_steps.description:
Today was one of the toughest days of the whole route 😮‍💨 In our guide, this path is described as ‘henro-korogashi’ which literally means ‘where a pilgrim falls down’. Which is what Bruno did. Multiple times 😅 
It was slippery, cold, rainy and steep 🌧️⛰️Only the beautiful Sakura trees were a nice distraction on our ascent. And our conversations 🧡
When we finally crossed the mountain and arrived at the temple we could eat inside, luckily 🤞There, we also met our new friend from today again, Natsuko-San, a Japanese woman from Hawaii. She’s lovely! Selfies coming soon 🤳
Peace out ✌️ 
Die müde Maike

all_steps.name: Temple 13-16 (or who jumps better?)
all_steps.description:
After an exhausting day yesterday going up the mountain ⛰️, we were rewarded today with a beautiful sight of the valley. Our host was also very kind to wash, dry and fold our clothes (and this lifts up the mood of any pilgrim 😊).
There was a long stretch before we could reach the first temple of the day, temple 13 (大日寺). Along the way we could once more enjoy the stunning views of the fully blossomed Sakura trees. After visiting temples 14 (常楽寺), 15 (国分寺) and 16 (観音寺) we reached our Ryokan, which is a fancier traditional japanese accommodation. Both me and Maike decided to put the vegetarianism aside and eat tuna sashimi 🍣 and we don’t regret: this Ryokan is known for its renowned chefs and the food was absolutely delicious 👨‍🍳😗 (*chefs kiss*).
Bruno 🧞‍♂️

all_steps.name: Temple 17-18
all_steps.description:
We are only on our fifth day of pilgrimage and we have already experienced so many acts of kindness from our hosts and from strangers that we cross paths with. 
On the previous days we had already received bottled water, oranges 🍊 and snacks from random people on our way. This morning, before we started our walk, our host gave us cookies that she baked herself. She also helped us with planning and booking for the next two nights, since a lot of accommodations are already fully booked and it’s becoming more and more difficult to find rooms.
After visiting temple 17 (井戸寺) and on our way to temple 18 (恩山寺) a young guy stopped his car close to us and offered ¥1000 💴 so we could buy some refreshment drinks. At first we refused but the guy kindly insisted, saying that he had walked the Shikoku Henro himself 5 years ago and that he was more than happy to offer us this osettai (gifts given to pilgrims of the Shikoku pilgrimage) 🙇‍♂️.
A bit before that, we crossed paths with a group of 7 or 8 old Japanese people that for some reason were a bit too excited to see us. After trying to understand why, we heard that apparently we were somehow on the national TV 📺 😎! We couldn’t understand much of the details but this didn’t stop our excitement to be almost famous now 😆. Hopefully we’ll hear more about this soon!
Bruno 🍙

all_steps.name: Temple 19-21
all_steps.description:
Today was “Bring-no-bagpack-to-your-hike-day”! Because we were staying two nights at the same place, we were fortunate to leave our belongings at the auberge today 😮‍💨 
Apparently the hike itself was not exhausting enough (we ‘only’ climbed the two steepest hills of the whole pilgrimage ⛰️) so I forced everybody to take some more jumping pictures 😎 Love them! 

Weisheit des Tages: Jumping without a bagpack is so much easier ! 😝

Maike 🌸

all_steps.name: Temple 22
all_steps.description:
Today we had our earliest start so far. At 6:00 sharp 🕕 our host drove us to the same spot where we finished our day yesterday, right after temple 21 (太龍寺). After a “quick” walk (about 10k) we arrived at temple 22 (平等寺), which was the only temple we visited today. While we were having breakfast there we saw two big groups of elderly japanese pilgrims which were all very polite and wished us a good day, one by one. We probably replied a hundred “Ohayoo gozaimasu” back to them.
On our way to our next accommodation (more than 20km walking distance), we were stopped twice in two different occasions by two japanese men wanting to help us showing a “better path” to the next temple. Both of them carefully explained an alternative route through the mountains instead of the normal route (which is on the road, through tunnels). They said that on the top of the mountain we would have a very nice view from the ocean 🌊 and it would be worth the extra effort.
They were absolutely right! After hiking up this alternative route, we were presented to an astonishing view of the ocean! There was even a swing there! It’s not everyday that you find yourself on a swing on the top of the mountain with an ocean view 😊! And we couldn’t have chosen a better day to see the ocean for the first time during this pilgrimage: the day was gorgeous, sunny and warm. On the top of the mountain we also met and had a nice chat with a japanese girl (Maya) who was walking the Henro with her mother. She lives in Shikoku and invited us to visit her after we finish our pilgrimage! 
The last kilometers along the coast were a bit exhausting (today we walked a total of 32km), but we arrived at our accommodation right before 5pm, which means that we had more than 10 hours hiking today!

Bruno 🐒

all_steps.name: Behind the scenes 👀
all_steps.description:
Meistens sind die Dinge nicht so wie sie scheinen 😜 Hier ein paar Fotos aus einer anderen Perspektive: 

1) Irgendwie müssen die ganzen Kirschblüten Fotos ja entstehen … 🌸
2) Bruno’s a photobomb 📸💣
3) Unser täglicher Stop am Supermarkt 🍙
4) Der Struggle die japanischen Zeichen zu verstehen (es gibt drei verschiedene Alphabete!)🈲
5) Luxus-Klo: alle Sitztoiletten hier haben eine beheizte Klobrille, Musik oder andere Töne und mindestens zwei Spüloptionen 🤪🚽
6) Wenn es regnet spielt Style keine Rolle mehr 🥸
7) Multikulti Abendessen 🍌🍠🥖🥟
8+9+10) Unsere verschiedenen Yukata Kimonos, die wir in fast jeder Unterkunft bekommen 👘 Nach der Dusche behalten wir sie zum Abendbrot und zum Schlafen an.

all_steps.name: Temple 23
all_steps.description:
We woke up at 6 and visited temple 23 (薬王寺) which was only 200m distant from our accommodation. The temple had a beautiful view to the bay and we could enjoy a beautiful sunrise. After that we came back and our lovely host cooked delicious oniguiris 🍙 (my favorite food from my childhood!) and tamagoyaki 🥚 for our breakfast and gave us more oniguiris and chocolate 🍫 as an osettai (gifts given to pilgrims of the Shikoku Pilgrimage) for us to have lunch on the way. It’s amazing how ours hosts have been spoiling us since the very beginning of this pilgrimage 👶🏻
We had three choices of paths for today: the shortest (of 20k), a “scenic” path (25k) and a “difficult and hilly but with astonishing views” path (4.5h through the mountains plus 15k). Of course we chose the easiest one 😌. We arrived at our accommodation (an old building with a sea view 🌊) at 2pm. We finally had some time to chill and do laundry 🧺 (two luxuries for a pilgrim 🙃).
Bruno 🍁

all_steps.name: First day without a temple
all_steps.description:
Since the distance from temple 23 to temple 24 is 77km, today was our first day with no temple visits. We chose also to take a slightly longer route to walk closer to the coast line and avoid the busy road (walking through tunnels is an experience that I don’t wish to anyone 😖). The path was full of beautiful views from the sea and from small beaches that we passed by along the way. 
We stopped for lunch at an awesome burger place recommended by Maya (the japanese girl we met three days ago, on our way to temple 23). We had vegan burgers and strawberry muffins and they were delicious 🍔🧁. The owner (which is Maya’s friend) was very welcoming as well.
After arriving at our accommodation, we changed to our swimwear and went for a dip in the ocean at the beach (which is 5 minutes walk from where we’re staying)! We cooked a big big pan of vegetables for dinner and are now making plans for a tough day tomorrow: the first four or five accommodations that we tried to book for tomorrow were already full, so we’re staying at a hotel that’s 40km away 🥵.

Bruno 🏊

all_steps.name: Still-no-temple-day
all_steps.description:
A little poem by Maike and Bruno:

All we have to say
it was a 40 Kilometer day.

✨

We’re out of here 🤙

all_steps.name: Temple 24-26
all_steps.description:
We finally visited temples again today (24, 25, 26)! 

Aaaand that was about it for the day 😝 It was a quite uneventful, I dare to say almost ‘boring’ day, that we mostly spent with walking along busy roads. I felt like I was on autopilot mode most of the time 🤖 Walking, eating and more walking. Hiker’s Hunger is a real thing btw, it seems as if we are constantly eating just to keep on walking 🚶‍♀️ 

Speaking of food, tonight we had an amazing home-cooked dinner by our lovely host lady. We ate cooked bamboo sticks, deep fried weeds from the beach and squid, just to mention a few dishes. Our host was so cute and curious to talk to us and get to know us ✨ Thanks to Google translate we can now call each other friends! 😉 One more kind soul we met along our path 👣

That’s it for today, boa noite! 
Maike 🧜‍♀️

all_steps.name: Temple 27
all_steps.description: On our way to temple 27 we were stopped by a very interesting person: a Japanese old man who has done the pilgrimage by car already multiple times and on his way of doing so he ‘collects’ pilgrims. Yes, collects 😎 He proudly showed us his notebook which stated that he had already met 1832 German pilgrims (No numbers for Brazil unfortunately 😵‍💫). In another notebook he showed us texts and photos of other German pilgrims he met and asked us if we can write something too ✍️ Of course we did! After marking my hometown Bocholt (I am apparently the first Bocholter on this pilgrimage!?) he took a picture of us with his flip phone and peeled us some oranges 🍊What a lovely osettai ! 😍

all_steps.name: No temples, lots of good food
all_steps.display_name: No temples, lots of good food
all_steps.description:
Today we had s short day (“only” 23km) and visited no temples. On our first break in the morning we met Natsuko again (a kind and smiley japanese lady who we’ve been meeting almost everyday since day 3!). We walked together for most of the day and in the end she invited us to join her on an onsen (the japanese public bath houses). I had a 1 hour massage and Maike with the rest of our party (Natsuko, Tani and Kyra) enjoyed two hours soaking on the onsen.
After that we were starving and went to a restaurant next door from our accommodation. The menu was in japanese, the waitress spoke only japanese and our solution was to ask the cook to bring us whatever he felt like cooking. The result? We had our best meal in Japan so far! We had Takenoko (bamboo shoots), konbu (sea weed), daikon (radish), karaage (deep fried chicken), chahan (fried rice), katsuo no tataki (broiled skipjack tuna sashimi) and lots of other things that we don’t even know the name. Everything was local, fresh and absolutely delicious!

all_steps.name: Temple 28-30
all_steps.description:
The day didn’t start promising: we didn’t have breakfast since we thought that it would be a 15km day, but soon we realized that we had made a planning mistake and we had to walk 25km instead. Also, it was pooouring 🌧️🌧️🌧️. It was our second rainy day since we started the pilgrimage, but by far the most intense one.
My rain jacket for some reason decided to absorb water instead of repelling it and Maike’s waterproof and blister-inducing shoes were retaining water inside instead of keeping water out. The result? I was completely soaked during the entire day and after we arrived at our hostel and Maike finally took her shoes off, her toes were so wrinkly that it looked like she had spent the whole day in the swimming pool.
Well, at least we avoided walking on main roads for most of the day and walked on side roads amongst rice fields (where we saw ducks 🦆, frogs 🐸 and even a tiny crab 🦀). We visited three more temples (28, 29 and 30) which were all a bit unimpressive. Tonight we sleep in one of the biggest cities of the Shikoku island (Kōchi). Actually we will spend two nights here since tomorrow is a day off!!! (our first since we started walking)

Bruno 🌧️

all_steps.name: Rest day in Kochi 🧘‍♀️
all_steps.description:
We celebrated our day off with a late (and delicious) breakfast. This time, we escaped from the traditional japanese-style breakfast (which usually includes rice, miso soup, fish and vegetables) to something more familiar to us: granola, fruits and yoghurt. And, for our second breakfast, we had cheesecake to celebrate Tani’s 30th birthday 🥳! Happy birthday, Tani! 🎈
The rain didn’t stop until 3pm so we chilled in our hostel room until we could finally breathe some fresh air outside. Our idea for today was to explore Kochi a little (the city is bigger than we thought) but Maike’s foot 🦶 is still not 100% recovered from yesterday so we didn’t do much other than going to a sports shop to find shorts 🩳 for Maike and a functioning rain jacket for me. We’re still debating what’s the best plan for tomorrow given the foot situation.
In the evening the girls went to the same restaurant from yesterday (apparently the food is really delicious 😋) for more birthday celebration and I stayed home drying everything I can with a blow dryer 💨.
Bruno 🫧

all_steps.name: Temple 31-34
all_steps.description:
Two pilgrims down already … and two versions of this day! ✌️

Maike:
This morning we said goodbye to our hiker friend Kyra, she is leaving Shikoku and will continue travelling to other places in Japan 🇯🇵 
Tani, Bruno and me continued to temple 31 but my left foot wasn’t too happy about this so I decided to take a bus to our hostel 😿 I did a quick stop in Kochi and found a new friend: a Japanese old man who sat next to me in the cafe 👴 Don’t ask me how but we ended up talking about parrot videos on Twitter, Elon Musk, ABBA and his favourite YouTube singer 👩‍🎤 I’m very glad I learned some Japanese before (and that Google Translate exists hehe). In the end he brought me some bread and chocolate as an osettai (See picture red bag) 🎁


Bruno:
This morning we said goodbye to Kyra — she had decided not to continue the pilgrimage with us and explore other parts of Japan instead. Her presence will be missed 😢
After walking to temple 31 (where we met Natsuko once more), Maike decided to take the bus straight to the next accommodation, skipping temples 32, 33 and 34. This has always been our rule number one for this pilgrimage: health comes first. 
I decided to keep walking (with Tani and Natsuko) and had a pleasant day. It was sunny and warm, unlike the past two days. Besides visiting the temples, taking one ferry ⛴️ and receiving cookies as osettai, not much happened during the walk.
I arrived at our hostel almost at 6pm and was happy to see Maike in good mood 💃We had dinner with our american roommate and decided to change our plans for the next days. But to know more, you have to check our polar steps tomorrow 😉

all_steps.name: Foot recovery part 1
all_steps.description:
Maike and I decided to take a few days off until her foot heals properly. Since we’re still in a relatively big city (Kōchi), we took the bus back to the city center and enjoyed a beautiful sunny Sunday. We walked through the Sunday Market, which we learned is one of the oldest (since 1690) and biggest (1.3km long) open markets in Japan! There we met Kyra and enjoyed a nice coffee together before giving her our goodbye again, this time for real.
We had a delicious lunch at another market (Hirome Market): katsuo no tataki (tuna sashimi, slightly grilled in an open flame, a traditional dish from this region) and had a white strawberry (!) as dessert.
We finished our day early to make sure that we get proper rest. Since there’s a shared kitchen at our accommodation, we decided to cook our signature dish in Japan: we buy all the vegetables that we can recognize at the supermarket and cook them together in a big pan! 🥦🍅🥬🥕🍠🧅 Yummy!

Bruno 🥗

all_steps.name: Restday (not so restday) part 2
all_steps.description:
As ex-Amsterdamers we love two things: bikes 🚲 and free stuff 🤑🆓 So even though the plan was to have a rest day today, we couldn’t resist the free rental bikes offered by the Kōchi Tourist Center. We didn’t want to walk, but nobody said that we couldn’t cycle to the temples 😉

It was another beautiful sunny day ☀️ and it was very pleasurable to cycle around. It took some time for us to get used to bike on the left side of the road, but by the end of the day we had cycled for almost 40km and visited temples 34, 33 and 32!

For dinner we had a delicious japanese curry 🍛 in a food court inside a beautiful book shop. We also reunited with our fellow hiker Tani, who finished her pilgrimage today and came back to spend one last night in Kōchi.

The rest days are doing good to Maike’s foot 🦶! Our plan is to take one more rest day tomorrow and restart our walking pilgrimage on Wednesday 🥾✌️

Bruno 🚵‍♂️

all_steps.name: Restday part 3
all_steps.description:
We had a lazy morning, slow breakfast, chill walk to the station to say goodbye to Tani, delicious vegan lunch at a nice restaurant, afternoon nap and bunch of vegetables for dinner. In short, a proper rest day 😌

Bruno 🧘‍♂️

PS: we are staying at this really cool place called Katsu Guest House which was designed by the owner herself with a lot of love for details ✨

all_steps.name: Temple 35
all_steps.description:
We’re back on ze road again! Quite literally: on our way to temple 35 we almost only walked along the streets 🚗🚛💨 

I am really glad we took those days off because my 🦶 feels a 100% fine again. Now I can’t wait to advance and walk and walk and walk. I think I’m appreciating the walking much more now 😉 

To finish: what kind of hiking day would it be if we didn’t receive an osettai? 🎁 On a particularly long and sunny stretch, a man handed us cold water he just bought. We really needed that, arigato gozaimasuuuu mister 🥵

Maike 🥾

all_steps.name: Temple 36
all_steps.description:
The day started with a quick stop at the convenience store to buy food for the day, since we knew we would have a stretch of ~20km without shops today. Right after that we had a short hike to temple 36 and decided to take a shortcut to continue the day…
Let’s say that the shortcut was not so short and we had a little adventure: After a few minutes following a hike path into the woods, we found ourselves a little bit lost, in a not-so-well maintained trail. We had to climb a hill here, walk through some rough vegetation there, but after half an hour we were back on track, just to find out that the shortcut didn’t save us any time nor kilometers. As you can see in the pictures, Maike was not so pleased 😅
Overall we had a pleasant day, with lots of sunshine but not too hot. We hiked most of the day with Quinten and David, two very chill and kind guys that we ran into during our visit to temple 36. At the end of the day we found out that we were all staying at the same accommodation so we went for dinner together, which ended up being the best ramen we had in Japan so far: a traditional local ramen from Susaki (the city we are in right now) named Nabeyaki Ramen 🍜.

Bruno 🥢

all_steps.name: 400km done ✅
all_steps.description:
Although we didn’t visit any temples, today we had a few accomplishments: it was the first day that we walked more than 30km after we took our rest days (36km to be more precise 😮‍💨). Also, we passed the 400km mark in total, which means that we’ve completed 1/3 of the entire pilgrimage! Cheers to us! 🏆
We started walking at 6am because not only we knew the day was long, but we had some steep parts (more than 600m of elevation) and we had some rain forecast for the end of the day, so we wanted to be sure to arrive safe and sound (and dry) at our accommodation. Everything went well and even though the rain arrived earlier than expected, it was fine to hike the last two hours under a light drizzle.
Our accommodation for tonight is a whole house 🏠! We booked only a room for two (like we always do) but when we arrived here we were told that they only rent the place for one group at a time. This means that we don’t have to pay anything extra but we have a 3-bedroom house entirely for us. Not bad 😎!
And finally but not least, we received a pack of strawberries 🍓 as an osettai today from a lady that was driving past us and stopped to give us a “presentto”. We’re feeling that we are the happiest and luckiest pilgrims today ✌️🍀.

Bruno 🍙

all_steps.name: Temple 37
all_steps.description:
Temple 37 was the most beautiful so far 🎨Japanese artist SHETA painted the entrance with beautiful heart motives and the temple’s inside was filled with 575 different drawings of e.g Buddha, flowers or even Marilyn Monroe! 

We found a cute café next door to hide from the rain ☔️ Here, you can see a pensive Bruno planning the next weeks already in his mind 😜 

As the rain didn’t stop (and I have bad bad memories from walking 25km in wet shoes) we decided to take the train to our accommodation 
for once 🚞  This gave us enough time to plan the coming days and also think about the „Golden week“ beginning of May, where the whole country has one week of holiday 🫣 Let’s see if we can find some places to stay then 🛌

Maike 🫰

all_steps.name: Oh happy day 🎶
all_steps.description:
When you do a long pilgrimage like the Shikoku Henro, there are always difficult days: days where your feet hurt, days where the rain never stops and you get soaking wet, days where you can’t find good food and you feel bad for eating so much crap. There are days where your accommodation sucks, days where your intestines don’t work like they should, days where you get furious because you overpay for things that you regret. There are days where you think “why the hell am I doing this?”.

And then, to balance it out, there are days like today 🤩!

We woke up with a beautiful view from our window, watching the sun rising in the ocean and had a tasty breakfast prepared by our 78 years old host. The day was beautiful and sunny, but not too hot. We quickly found public toilets for the two or three times that either me or Maike needed to pee. We met David again along the way and had a very nice chat. We found a beach and went for a quick dip in the sea. We had the best coffee we had so far in Japan and received delicious cookies as osettai from the lovely coffee shop owner. We had a mouth-watering Okonomiyaki for dinner which was cooked right in front of us. And even though we hiked for more than 26km, we could barely feel any tiredness at the end of the day.

There are these days where you just cannot complain about life 🤍🥰

Bruno 🍪

all_steps.name: Temple 38
all_steps.description:
We took the bus down to Ashizuri cape, the most southern part of Shikoku island where temple 38 is located. This temple was one of the most beautiful ones, with a big pond, trees and flowers all around 🌳🌸 
We continued to explore ‚The seven wonders of Ashizuri‘ with one of them being an eroded hole in the cliff and the other one a stone that looks like a 🐢. Can you see the turtle already? 😜 

Maike 🗿

all_steps.name: Temple 39 - 40
all_steps.description:
Another good day is coming to an end, here, on this side of the planet 🌌
We came at 6am to an empty station to take the first train to temple 39. From there, we started our 31km day hike to temple 40 🏯 
We met some funny fellows today: this perfect-looking, straight-from-my-childhood-drawings frog 🐸 and a very friendly and chatty Japanese cyclist who gave us energy bars and showed us the way to a much more beautiful and scenic mountain trail 🗻 This trail, the Matsuo Tōge, had the cutest motivational signs handmade from elementary school kids 🫠 You can find a selection of the best ones in the pictures.
We indeed completed the trail and the rest of the day very motivated and cheered up, gambatte! 💪 
Now, it’s time to rest well before another long day of around 40km tomorrow. Ab in die Pofe ! 

Maike ⏰

all_steps.name: What our days look like
all_steps.description:
Even though every day is unique and special on its own (especially when reflecting upon it in the evenings), the days all together feel more or less the same. They become this one big blur 🌀Sounds paradoxical but … do you know what I mean?
To demonstrate, I can explain to you our rhythm of a ‘normal’ day: 

5am - 6am 🕕 
The alarm rings at 5 but most of the time I don’t hear it and Bruno is already awake half an hour earlier anyways 🙃 We always always have breakfast otherwise we can’t leave the house 😜 Of course we eat good ol‘ Müsli, fruits and … 
🙌peanutbutter🙌. After stretching we start our hike at 6.

10am 🕙 
Time for a second breakfast! Best kind of breakfast hehe 🫠 If we’re lucky we find a convenience store around that time. There you can find all kinds of food and we buy some 🍙 and 🥕 and eat it in the parking lot (see picture). That’s the life! 😎 

Until 3/4pm 🕓
Walking, walking, talking, eating, singing, walking, arriving! After the check-in at each place we are called via the room telephone to our showers. After shower we chill for a bit in a very hot tub called ofuro ♨️ It’s good for the sore muscles (and stretching again helps a lot too) 💪 

6pm 🕕 
Dinner time! We either buy some Bento 🍱 boxes at the supermarket, eat at a restaurant or if we have a kitchen we cook 👩‍🍳  Most of the times we’re lazy and … cook 😝 

9pm 🕘 
Hop in the kimono, quickly write a loooong Polarsteps post and then it’s time to sleep 😴 9pm is the new midnight here! With that said: Gute Nacht 😘 

Maike 🐰

all_steps.name: Temple 41-43
all_steps.description:
The morning started how we liked: waking up without alarm (at 5:30 😴), having a delicious breakfast (musli, yoghurt, blueberry 🫐, kiwi 🥝) and filtered coffee with oat milk (!) ☕️. We left our beautiful accommodation at 7 on the dot.

On our first temple of the day (41) we had a delightful surprise and met our friend Natsuko (the lovely Japanese lady who we met on our first days of pilgrimage!). We walked with her (and her friend) for the rest of the day.

It was a very pleasant day, where we walked mostly through forests and beautiful passes (we learned that the word “pass” means “a route over or through mountains”). We even went through a nice path where a few years ago a typhoon 🌪️ caused a flood and made the trail impassable. Apparently this year is the first year since that part of the trail is open again. We had to go over (and under) lots of trees and branches that had been knocked over by either the tornado or flood. 

Even though we haven’t visited half of the temples yet (almost there!), today we realized that we are past the half of our pilgrimage in kilometers: we have walked more than 650km so far!

PS: Natsuko is really fascinated by the way we eat carrots. Every time she sees us eating a whole carrot 🥕 she laughs and takes a picture 😂📸

Bruno 🐍

all_steps.name: Just a regular everyday normal day
all_steps.display_name: Just a regular everyday normal day
all_steps.description:
Today was what we call “a boring day”: we left our accommodation at 7:30 (super late!), had a non-ambitious hike (20km) and the day went by with no major events. Except that we saw our first snake on this pilgrimage 🐍 (and almost stepped on it 😵‍💫).

Bruno 🍝

all_steps.name: Kuriositäten am Wegesrand
all_steps.description:
After walking for more than 700km we have seen quite some strange/funky/interesting things along the roads. Here are some of them:

1-3) Nature taking over - Random electronic waste in the middle of nowhere. We learned that giving up your car costs a lot of money here, so many people simply abandon their old cars in the forest.

4) TAKENOKO! 🎍It’s a new growing bamboo tree (a baby bamboo 👶) You can eat the stem and it’s delicious! 

5) A teeny tiny toilet along the way. I think it’s for kids …

6) Soft drinks vending machine paradise! 🧋🧃🥤

7) A phone holder for the perfect picture 🤳

8) A completely pink (!) gas station 💗💗💗

9) „Do you want to build a snowman?“ ☃️Someone rebuild a winter scene and the Shikoku pilgrims in their classic Ohenro outfit.

all_steps.name: Is it breakfast or dinner?
all_steps.description:
Breakfast in Japan is so different than the one I usually eat at home. Here, I have already eaten more fish for breakfast than in my entire life before (I actually only ate salmon really before becoming vegetarian) 🐟 
There is always rice and miso soup (misoshiro), green tea and salted ‘Nori’ to make your own mini-sushi. Pickles and something like scrambled eggs but much much better called ‘Tamagoyaki’ cannot be missed either! The exact same food can be found at the dinner table too, just with more variations of fish. And tempura 🍤😋 But to be honest, a lot of times I don’t even know what I’m eating exactly 🤦‍♀️ So, it’s up to you now to decide which one of those two pictures is breakfast or dinner !? 

At 7:30, after having this delicious breakfast this morning (the best one so far) we accidentally went for a 20km sprint and already arrived at 12:30 at our accommodation for the night! Oops, I guess this means we had another chill day of reading, napping and eating 🤭

Maike 🍣

all_steps.name: Temple 44-45
all_steps.description:
Today we had a “loop day”: we started and finished the day at the same spot, meaning that we could leave our backpack at the hotel and walk light. Even though we walked for 26km, it feels almost like a rest day.

The weather was milder than the past days and we hiked most of the time on unpaved terrain. Also, the two temples that we visited today were astonishing. Temple 44 was on top of a hill, surrounded by beautiful trees. Temple 45 was probably the most impressive temple we visited so far (it’s our second favorite, only behind the colorful temple 37 🌈).

No backpacks, nice weather, no roads, lots of nature and beautiful temples? This is the recipe for a perfect day!

PS: Temple 45 was really spectacular. We arrived through a dense forest, with massive trees 🌲. On its approach we passed by 36 Buddhas statues 🗿 and a locked gate that gives access to a challenging (and apparently dangerous) climb  🧗‍♀️ on the big rocks 🪨 that surround the temple (you have to request the key at the temple but we preferred not to risk our lives this time 😅). We were content to “only” climb a ladder 🪜 that led us to a cave on the rock just above the temple.

Bruno 🐿️

all_steps.name: Temple 46-51
all_steps.description:
The forecast for today was rain, rain and more rain. So, after having a late breakfast at the hotel (7 AM), we had no choice other than start our walk at 7:40 under a light drizzle. It was probably the coldest morning since we started our pilgrimage (7°) and we knew that it would be a long day (6 temples over 32 km).

On days like this, my strategy is to always think “well, it could be worse”. It was raining, but it was not pouring. It was cold, but not freezing. We had to walk 32km, but at least it was not 40. See? It could be worse!

We arrived at our hostel after 5 PM completely exhausted and besides visiting 6 temples (which is our record for number of temples visited in one single day), the other highlights of the day were: a beautiful mist over the forest 🌫️; cute notes by children giving us the much appreciated support to keep going 💪; Maike eating peanut butter from the jar like a true hiker should do; and an absolutely delicious probiotic vegan dinner here in Matsuyama (where we will be staying for two days).

Bruno 🥬

all_steps.name: Temple 52-53
all_steps.description:
After having breakfast at a Starbucks 🫣 we walked around Matsuyama. We passed by the famous Dōgo Onsen (it’s a 3000+ years old bath house) but to be honest, we were not impressed. We enjoyed much more the colorful art exposition on the surroundings of the onsen.

From there we took a tram and a train to temple 52 and then walked to temple 53. The weather changed completely, and the day turned from a cold and rainy morning to a beautiful, sunny and warm afternoon.

Bruno 🍵

all_steps.name: Temple 54-59
all_steps.description:
After having used bikes, bus and train we can now proudly say that we have finally added a taxi 🚕 to our portfolio 🙌  Well, how did that happen? Keep reading.

This morning we took two trains and eventually started to walk at 8:30. Our latest start so far! At our second temple we had a nice conversation with a fellow pilgrim from Denmark 🇩🇰 which already put a smile on our faces 😊 Then, we ran into our friend from temple 27 (see post there): the pilgrim collector! Again, we wrote a little text in his book and again he took a picture with his flip phone. “Man sieht sich immer zweimal” like ze Germans say seems to be true! 

Somehow though our day ended up being longer than expected, with the two pleasant surprises as mentioned above and a 20km day that turned out to be more of a 30km day 😮‍💨 When we got off our last train a beautiful, magical, very tempting taxi was waiting around … and suddenly arriving in 8 minutes by 🚕instead of 1 hour by 🚶‍♀️ becomes very tempting when you’re exhausted and hungry, let me tell you this! And the rest is history 🏛️

Maike 🍟

all_steps.name: Temple 60-64
all_steps.description:
We’ve been very lucky with our accommodations since the first day of our pilgrimage and yesterday was no exception. Our host, this lovely 70 years old lady, was so welcoming and so delightful that we felt right at home since the moment we arrived. We had a great time in the evening chatting with her and another friendly Japanese guest. In the morning, after having breakfast and chat a bit more, it was time to say goodbye and start our walk to temple 60 — a henro korogashi (which are difficult passages from the pilgrimage, literally meaning “where pilgrims fall”).

The weather once more was perfect and we had a very pleasant day (even though we had to wait a snake 🐍 slowly walk away from our path 😰). Some of the temples were surprising and some were a little bit disappointing, but what matters is that we visited 5 more temples today (60 to 64). At the end of the day we had to rush a little bit to make sure that we didn’t miss our train (temple run 😅). In the end, all went well 🚂

Bruno 🧖

all_steps.name: Temple 65
all_steps.description:
Unfortunately this text has been deleted and I cannot seem to find it on Bruno’s or my phone 😥 So here goes my memory (now, one week later 🐘) : this day was pretty normal, we left our great hotel where we had the onsen for ourselves and a TV with Netflix (a luxury for a pilgrim!!) to embark on a 30km day. Along the way we saw some monkeys 🙊 We arrived at our place for the night pretty early. It’s a place owned by a 94 year old man! 

Maike 🍪

all_steps.name: Shopping Day 🛍️
all_steps.description:
After walking more than 800km on this pilgrimage, I think we can all agree that it was about time for me to get new shoes 👟 and socks 🧦!

Bruno 🦶

all_steps.name: Temple 66-67
all_steps.description:
Since today we would start the day with a Henro Korogashi (the difficult passages of the Shikoku 88 temples pilgrimage), we had breakfast at 6am and soon after we began our ascent to temple 66, the highest temple of the whole pilgrimage. Two hours later we arrived at the temple (which is located at an elevation of 911 meters) and thankfully we had obentos 🍙 prepared by our 94 year old host (and packed in a newspaper 🗞️😅), since there was no other way of getting food up there.

We had no surprises for the rest of the day. From temple 66 we walked down for about two hours more and visited temple 67 and yet again another two hours stretch to our accommodation.

Bruno 🤙

all_steps.name: Temple 68-70
all_steps.description:
Our journey is coming to an end … almost! More than 900km are done, less than 300km to be walked. We’re in the final stretch of our hike. And we can feel it 😮‍💨 My feet are slowly dissolving (whatever that means to you) and so are my shoes. Bruno’s back is hurting. The temples are becoming less interesting. Writing Polarsteps is becoming a task, just like taking our mandatory selfies at the temples. 
But (big BUT) we accept the challenge! These feelings, this ‘low’, it’s all part of the journey 👣 Next Monday we will finish and be missing the time spent outside, our random conversations, the kindness of strangers, the exhaustion and maybe even the temples (big MAYBE here) 😝 

No more emotional 🦀, back to our day: what a lazy day! Because we ‘only’ had 15km to walk, we decided to take a detour and go to the beach in the morning. Unfortunately the beach was very much concrete and bushes and no sand so we had to skip that part 🥲 After visiting our 3 temples for today we passed the time until check-in at different Kombinis or supermarkets 🛒 Tonight’s accommodation is a really cool place, owned by a young family who built it themselves 👨‍👩‍👦‍👦  Cheers! 

Maike 🧦

all_steps.name: Temple 71-76
all_steps.description:
Today was our last “easy day” (less than 20km) from the pilgrimage. Also, we broke the 1000km mark since we started! More and more we’re having the feeling that we’re almost there 😬!

We visited temples 71 to 76 and the highlight of the day was definitely temple 75. This temple is so important that the whole city is named after the temple (Zentsūji). The reason for that is because Zentsūji is the birthplace of Kūkai, which is this guy who is accredited with founding the Shikoku pilgrimage. And since this year would be his 1250th birthday, there were some celebrations happening there. It was by far the busiest temple we visited until now (also because it’s Golden Week here in Japan, a big holiday week).

Bruno 🎈

all_steps.name: Temple 77-80
all_steps.description:
Heute war ein Tag der Begegnungen 💫

Angefangen mit einem Paar, das mich am zweiten Tempel des Tages (Nr. 78) zu sich rief und mir Donuts und Tee gab. Mit meinen drei Sätzen Japanisch und mit ein ganz bisschen Englisch hatten wir sogar ein nettes Pläuschen 🤭
Grade hatten wir den Tempel hinter uns gelassen, da rief uns die nächste Frau zu 👋 Die nette alte Dame fragte uns auf Englisch ob wir denn wissen was ein Osettai sei und ob wir eins möchten. Und ob! Natürlich sagen wir nie nein zu einem Geschenk und einer Pause 😉 Im Haus gab sie uns ebenfalls Tee und 🍪 Sie erzählte uns ganz stolz wie sie Englisch gelernt hat als sie bemerkt hat, dass immer mehr Touristen in ihre Stadt kommen. Und dass sie nur Mittwochs und Samstags Osettais verteilt, so ein Glück für uns! 
Als wir am Ende des Tages eine Pause beim Konbini einlegten, trafen wir einen älteren Japaner der perfekt deutsch sprach. Er hat in Tübingen als Arzt praktiziert und hatte sogar ein bisschen einen schwäbischen Akzent! 😅 Am Ende gabs eine Süßigkeit und sogar eine Umarmung! 
Dieser Tag reiht sich ein in die vielen anderen Tage davor, in denen Fremde so nett zu uns gewesen sind 🥰

Maike 🫂

all_steps.name: Temple 81-83
all_steps.description:
Today we walked 26km and visited 3 temples: 81, 82 and 83. The way to the first two temples was on a forest path, so even though the day was very sunny and warm, we didn’t notice until we started walking in the city.
We had three highlights today: first, we saw a cat monkey on our path 🐱🐵 (no pictures, unfortunately). Second, we had the nicest “osettai stop” ever (see the picture about Keiko's Reception Place). And third, we are staying in a guest house owned by a monk who also studies Japanese culinary kitchen. He cooked the most delicious dinner for us and three other Japanese guests and, after introducing ourselves (in Japanese), we ate together while chatting about traveling in a curious mix of Japanese and English. Sugoi!

Bruno 🥢

all_steps.name: Temple 84-85
all_steps.description:
We left the guesthouse with a coffee and a smile on our faces after a nice chat with the owner, a monk. Our 30km day ahead looked bright and sunny 🌞 … until I lost my smile while climbing what felt like the looongest mountain so far 😖 Of course Bruno captured it with a selfie! At the second temple, we took the cable car up instead and met our friend Natsuko again. She stayed there while we already continued to our accommodation. Half an hour later, a running pilgrim overtook us, shouting „you’re too slow!“ 🏃‍♀️ It was Natsuko - running for her train 😅

Maike 🍦

PS: the caterpillar looks so cool, no? 🐛💚

all_steps.name: Temple 86-88
all_steps.description:
Today was the day! Now we can proudly say we have seen it all 😎 ‘It’ in our case stands for the 88 temples of Shikoku island 🏯📿🎋

How did it go, the day we’ve been waiting for so long?
Overall it was a pretty slow day. I guess we felt a little lazy or ‘temple-tired’ 😴 It’s a thing! After having visited Nr. 86 and Nr. 87 it was time for our certificate (we didn’t even officially reach the end but who cares 🤭) Before the pilgrims start their final climb to the last one, temple 88, they can collect their completion certificate at a museum at the bottom of the hill. There, they had a cool 3D map of the pilgrimage and some interesting statistics 📊 
Two certificates, a picture and a couple of snacks later we continued our journey. Because we have been warned last week by another pilgrim that the last climb would be very difficult, even dangerous, we decided to take the safe but longer route along the road 🚗 When we finally arrived we were lucky to catch Natsuko and two other Brazilians still! They had to run for the bus (again!) but of course Bruno managed a quick selfie with almost everybody 🤳 We learned from them that the climb wasn’t so hard after all! 

Now, one might think our journey is over … but we’ve decided to come full circle ⭕️ and continue to temple 1, where it all started. So two more days of hiking and then you’re finally getting rid of us! 🥹

Maike & Bruno 👣

all_steps.name: The almost-last-day
all_steps.description:
Our highlights of an otherwise rainy, boring day:

🎁 A young man coming out of nowhere and chasing after us to give us water and chocolate breads as an osettai!🚰🍞 He wished us ‘Ganbatte 💪’ and ran away again. And all of that in the pouring rain 🌧️ 

🪑 Finding shelter from the rain at an abandoned hotel and discovering two (very dirty) chairs to sit on. There’s no better way to enjoy our guilty-pleasure-food, peanutbutter with Müsli 😍 Made us feel like true hikertrash 🥹 

Maike 😴

all_steps.name: Temple 1 (full circle complete!)
all_steps.description:
They say “it’s not the destination, it’s the journey”. Well, that might be true. But I must say that arriving at your destination after having walked almost 1200km in 45 days feels *awesome*! 🏆

Bruno 🟣

all_steps.name: Last post and next steps
all_steps.description:
Better (one week) late than never:

For the past 50 days, Polarsteps was part of every single one of our evenings. Sometimes 🙂, sometimes 🙃. Not the app in particular but the creation of texts: reflecting on our day, trying to wrap up our experiences in words, finding the right angle. It became our diary and the digital, shared memory of our hike. 
To not forget - that was our motivation. 

But even more motivating than merely wanting to remember, was knowing that you are reading! To hope that you are maybe maybe smiling at our texts and pictures, that you like and enjoy these memories as much as we did 🥰 
To everyone who sent us their kindness through likes, comments or private messages; to everyone who in some way or another followed along our crazy journey of 88 temples - thank you, obrigado and dankeeeee 💜🧡

Now that one week has passed, all the pain and exhaustion is forgotten and we already try to walk as much as we can again 🤪 Which is working well because from now on we’ll be visiting the big cities in Japan 🇯🇵 🏙️ We’ll create another Polarsteps Trip soon! 

Maike & Bruno 🙇‍♀️🙇‍♂️
